discussion.content: wouldn't SAS be the better option?
The answer is A., SAS drives have higher transfer speeds (3 or 6Gbit/s, as opposed to a maximum of 5120 Mbit/s for SCSI)

questions.question_text:
Users have reported that the speed on a server is too slow for an application. After examining the server, the server technician determines that the server has
SATA drives. Which of the following types of drives should the technician install to improve the server's performance?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
RFID chips on the laptops – (Tracks laptop movement), Cable lock on the laptops – (Physically secures laptops in place)

questions.question_text:
An administrator notes laptops have been removed from a secure area. Which of the following strategies will BEST ensure laptops remain in the secured area?
(Choose two.)

choices.E: Security camera in the secure area

choices.D: Connect redundant power supplies to the same PDUs
choices.E: Connect all rack PDUs to the UPS battery
choices.B: Connect servers with multiple power supplies to separate power sources
choices.F: Connect servers with multiple power supplies to the same higher-amp circuits
choices.C: Periodically test the UPS batteries to ensure they are fully charged
choices.A: Connect the rack PDUs to separate power circuits

discussion.content: I think this should be C and E. The power loss happened already.

comments.content: power loss has not happened, the MOST uptime in the event of a sudden power loss is required for a new install. C is not applicable in the scenario, def belongs to maintenance tasks rather than redundancy planning.
E is not good either with its one point failure

I think C is more like for maintenance. 
I think we need UPS (option E) for sure but A and B also seem fair to me.

questions.question_text: A new rack of servers has been installed in a datacenter. A server administrator needs to ensure fault tolerance and redundancy wherever possible. Which of the following would ensure the MOST uptime in the event of a sudden power loss? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C seems more logical. If the other user can access the file share, then the issue is likely specific to the original user's profile or cached credentials.

questions.question_text: A user was set up with a new computer and is now unable to access a file share on the server. The user was previously able to access the file share from the old computer. The administrator knows the user can access other network resources, and the user's security permissions remain the same. Which of the following is the NEXT logical step for the administrator to troubleshoot this issue?

choices.C: Log in to this computer as a different user and attempt to browse to the share
choices.D: Check security permissions on the file share for this user
choices.A: Ping the server from this computer to see if there is a response
choices.B: Log in to another computer as this user and attempt to browse to the share

questions.question_text: A hardware vendor contacts an administrator about a critical firmware update. Which of the following resources would the administrator MOST likely consult to determine which systems are affected?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C contains detailed information about all hardware assets, including model numbers, serial numbers, hardware configurations, and firmware versions. B contains the age or phase of the systems, it doesn't provide details about which systems are affected by firmware update.
